sentence:
A graph G is said to be -convergent if {^n(G): n ‚àà‚Ñï} is finite; otherwise it is -divergent .

A graph H is said to be an -root of G if (H) is isomorphic to G, (H)‚âÖ G.
The -depth of G is 

    sup{n ‚àà‚Ñï : G‚âÖ^n(H)  for some graph  H}.

The -depth of a graph G that has no -root is said to be zero.

The graph G is said to be -periodic if there exists a positive integer n such that ^n(G)=G.  The least such integer is called the -periodicity of G.  
If n=1, G is called -stable .

sentence:
Let A = (Œ±_1,Œ±_2,‚Ä¶,Œ±_k,Œ±_k+1) be a
    (k+1)-tuple of permutations of [n] in which Œ±_k+1 is the
    identity permutation. Let
    M = (Œº_1,Œº_2,‚Ä¶,Œº_k) be a k-tuple of
    operation sequences, each of length n+1.
    We call T=(A,M) a trace of length n and

  *  The word Œº_i records the sequence of
      operations performed by the pop-stack operator when applied to
      Œ±_i‚Äîin symbols, (Œ±_i)=Œº_i. As to the
      picture of the trace, two adjacent numbers form an ascent if and

sentence:
Let T be a semitrace of length n and let a and b be two
  distinct elements of [n]. We call (a,b) a violating pair of
  T if, in any row, a and b occur in adjacent positions such that
  they violate Property¬†<ref>. That is, a and b form a
  descent and are separated by a bar, or a and b form an ascent and
  are not separated by a bar.

  M. Then we call S = œà^-1(c_ic_i+1‚Ä¶ c_j) a

sentence:
A segment
  T_a,b is forbidden if, after inferring the positions of
  a and b in rows 2 to
  k, either the two numbers violate Property¬†<ref> on row
  i, where 2 ‚â§ i ‚â§ k, or
  
  
  *  a and b form a descent on row 2 and, if
    a and b are in columns i and i+1 on row 2, there is no bar
    separating columns i and i+1 on row 1, or
  
  *  a and
    b are in decreasing order on row 2 and, if a and
    b are in columns i and j on row 2, with
    i<j, there is a bar immediately to the left of column
    i on row 1, a bar immediately to the right of column j on row
    1, and exactly one bar between columns i and j on row 1.
  
  In both cases the bars that we reference belong to the segment
  T_a,b. In other words, we can determine if
  T_a,b is forbidden or not without knowing in which semitrace it is embedded.

sentence:
A segment of order k is bounded if each of its blocks in rows
  2 to k has size at most 3. Equivalently, a segment is bounded
  if its operation array has no occurrence of three consecutive 's on
  rows 2 to k.

sentence: A matching in a graph G is a set of edges such that no two of them  have a vertex in common. The number of edges in a matching is called the size of that matching . The collection of all matchings of size k in a graph G is denoted by ‚Ñ≥_k(G). We define m_k(G)=|‚Ñ≥_k(G)| with the convention that m_0(G)=1.  A matching is called maximal if it is not contained in any other matching. The largest possible cardinality among all matchings is called the matching number of G.

sentence:
Given a hypergraph G an orientation (ùîû,ùîü) of a hyperedge U‚àà G is an ordered set partition (ùîû,ùîü) of U. 
We can think of the orientation (ùîû,ùîü) as current or flow on U from a single vertex ùîû to the vertices in ùîü in which case we say that ùîû is the head of the orientation ùîû‚Üíùîü of U.
It what follows we will want to think of the vertices in ùîû as being contracted to a single point while the vertices in ùîü remain as distinct points.
If |U|=n, then there are a total of 2^n-2 possible orientations. An  orientation of G is an orientation of all its hyperedges. Given an orientation ùí™  on G, we say that (ùîû,ùîü)‚ààùí™ if (ùîû,ùîü) is the orientation of a hyperedge U in G.

sentence:
A floor diagram  on a vertex set {1, ‚Ä¶, d} is a
directed graph (possibly with
multiple edges) with edge weights w(e) ‚àà_>0
satisfying:


  * The edge directions preserve the vertex order, i.e., for each
  edge i ‚Üí j of  we have i
  < j.

  * (Divergence Condition) For each vertex j of :

    div(j) def=‚àë_[ edges e;  j e‚Üí k ] w(e) -   ‚àë_[ edges e;  i e‚Üí j ] w(e)‚â§ 1.




This means that at every vertex of  the total weight of the outgoing edges
is larger by at most 1 than the total weight of the incoming edges.

 Step 1: Fix a pair of collections of sequences ( {Œ±^i

sentence:
Let n=(n_1,‚Ä¶,n_s-1)‚àà_2^s-1, let x‚àà_r and let C_n,x be the cycle of length four of (2,r,s) given by 

    ((0,n,x),(n,0,x+1),(1,n,x),(n,1,x+1)).

Then :={C_n,x|n‚àà_2^s-1,x‚àà_r} is a cycle decomposition of (2,r,s) into cycles of length four called the natural cycle decomposition of (2,r,s). 
As the arc-transitive action of _2‚âÄ_r on (2,r,s) induces a transitive action on , we see that  is arc-transitive.
The graph ((2,r,s),) is simply denoted by ((2,r,s)).

It is not hard to see that the graph ((2,r,s)) can also be described in the following way: its vertex-set is _2^s√ó_r√ó{+,-} and its edge-set is 
    {{(n_0,‚Ä¶,n_s-1,x,+),(n_1,‚Ä¶,n_s,x+1,-)}| n_i‚àà_2,x‚àà_r}¬†‚à™


    {{(n_0,‚Ä¶,n_s-1,x,+),(n_0,‚Ä¶,n_s-1,x,-)}| n_i‚àà_2,x‚àà_r}.

Observe that the wreath product W:=_2‚âÄ_r=_2^r‚ãä_r has a faithful action on (Œì)=_2^s√ó_r√ó{+,-}. Namely, for g=(g_0,‚Ä¶,g_r-1,h)‚àà W (with g_0,‚Ä¶,g_s-1‚àà_2 and h‚àà_r), we have 

    (n_0,n_1,‚Ä¶,n_s-1,x,¬±)^g=(n_0^g_x,n_1^g_x+1,‚Ä¶,n_s-1^g_x+s-1,x^h,¬±)  if  h‚àà_r,
    
    (n_0^g_x,n_1^g_x+1,‚Ä¶,n_s-1^g_x+s-1,x^h,‚àì)  otherwise,

where the indices are taken modulo r. It is easy to check that W is a vertex-transitive group of automorphisms of ((p,r,s)).

sentence:
Let ùíú be a (possibly infinite) set of linear hyperplanes in V:=‚Ñù^r and let T be an open convex cone in V. We say that ùíú is locally finite in T if for every x ‚àà T  there exists a neighbourhood U_x ‚äÇ T of x, such that { H ‚ààùíú| H ‚à© U_x ‚â†‚àÖ} is finite. A hyperplane arrangement (of rank r) is a pair (ùíú,T), where T is a convex open cone in V, and ùíú is a set of linear hyperplanes such that the following holds: 

  * H ‚à© T ‚â†‚àÖ for all H ‚ààùíú,

  * ùíú is locally finite in T.

Denote by T the topological closure of T with respect to the standard topology of V. If X ‚äÇT then the localization at X (in ùíú) is defined as 
    ùíú_X:= { H ‚ààùíú  |   X ‚äÇ H }.
 
In the case X= { x } we write ùíú_x instead of A_{ x } and call (ùíú_x, T) the parabolic subarrangement at x.  The connected components of T ‚àñ‚ãÉ_H ‚ààùíú H are called chambers or cells . If K is a chamber then its walls are given by the hyperplanes contained in the set 
    W^K:= { H ‚â§ V   |  dim(H)= r-1, ‚ü® H ‚à©K‚ü©_‚Ñù=H, H ‚à© K = ‚àÖ}.

The arrangement (ùíú, T) is called thin if W^K ‚äÇùíú for each chamber K. A simplicial hyperplane arrangement (of rank r) is an arrangement (ùíú, T) such that each chamber K is an open simplicial cone. T is called the Tits cone of the arrangement. Finally, a simplicial arrangement is called a Tits arrangement if it is also thin.

sentence:
Let the pair (ùíú, T) be a Tits arrangement and denote the set of chambers by ùí¶. Then we have the following thin chamber complex 
    ùíÆ(ùíú, T):= {K‚à©‚ãÇ_H ‚àà X H   |   K ‚ààùí¶, X ‚äÇ W^K },
 
whose poset-structure is given by set-wise inclusion. The 0-simplices of ùíÆ(ùíú, T) are called vertices and the 1-simplices of ùíÆ(ùíú, T) are called segments or edges . We call the Tits arrangement (ùíú, T) locally spherical if all vertices meet T. If v is a vertex of ùíú then we define its weight to be w(v):=|ùíú_v|. If K is the closure of a chamber K with supporting hyperplanes H_1, H_2, H_3 ‚ààùíú, then the Coxeter diagram Œì^K associated to K is the weighted undirected graph with vertices H_1, H_2, H_3 and edges between H_i, H_j if and only if |ùíú_H_i ‚à© H_j|>2; in this case the weight of the edge between H_i, H_j is exactly the quantity |ùíú_H_i ‚à© H_j|. We agree that edge weights less than four are omitted. The Tits arrangement ùíú is called irreducible if Œì^K is connected for any chamber K of ùíú. A rank three Tits arrangement which is not irreducible is called a near pencil .

a) Let œÉ be an irreducible conic in ‚Ñô^2(‚Ñù) and consider a subset M ‚äÇœÉ. There exists a projectivity Œ® such that Œ®(œÉ) is given by the polynomial P:=x^2+y^2-z^2 and is thus contained entirely in the affine z=1 patch of ‚Ñô^2(‚Ñù). We say that p_1,...,p_k ‚àà M are consecutive with respect to Œ®, if for any 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ k-1 it is true that one of the segments on Œ®(œÉ) bounded by Œ®(p_i),Œ®(p_i+1) contains no other point of Œ®(M).

sentence:
A staircase tableau of size n is a Young diagram of ‚Äústaircase"
shape (n, n-1, ‚Ä¶, 2, 1) such that boxes are either empty or
labeled with Œ±, Œ≤, Œ≥, or Œ¥, subject to the following conditions:


  * no box along the diagonal is empty;

  * all boxes in the same row and to the left of a Œ≤ or a Œ¥ are empty;

  * all boxes in the same column and above an Œ± or a Œ≥ are empty.

The type () of a staircase tableau 
is a word in {‚àò, ‚àô}^n

obtained by reading the diagonal boxes from
northeast to southwest and writing a ‚àô for each Œ± or Œ¥,
and a ‚àò for each Œ≤ or Œ≥.

sentence:
The weight () of a staircase tableau  is a monomial in
Œ±, Œ≤, Œ≥, Œ¥, q, and u, which we obtain as follows.
Every blank box of  is assigned a q or u, based on the label of the closest
labeled box to its right in the same row and the label of the closest labeled box
below it in the same column, such that:


  * every blank box which sees a Œ≤ to its right gets a u;

  * every blank box which sees a Œ¥ to its right gets  a q;

  * every blank box which sees an Œ± or Œ≥ to its right,
  and an Œ± or Œ¥ below it, gets  a u;

  * every blank box which sees an Œ± or Œ≥ to its right,
  and a Œ≤ or Œ≥ below it, gets a q.

After filling all blank boxes,
we define ()
to be the product of all labels in all boxes.

sentence:
[Characterization of the Maximum Independent
    Sets of ùêÅ(ùêù,3)]
  
  For all positive d we have:
  
  
  *  Any orbit of independent sets of
    B(d,3) under the action of S_d is obtained from the
     {0 0 0} and the orbit of {0 0
    0 ,0 1 0,1 1 1} under S_2 by a unique sequence
    of applications of f, f', g, and g'.
  
  *  Let S be an MIS of B(d,3). Then the
    subgroup of S_d stabilizing S is generated by disjoint
    transpositions. In particular, the cardinality of the
    stabilizer of¬†S is a power of¬†2.
  
  *  Let b_d,k be the number of orbits of
    MISs in B(d,3) whose elements have stabilizers of size
    2^k. Then we have the recurrence relation
    
    b_1,0 = 1,  
            b_2,0 = 3,
    
            b_d,k = 2b_d-1,k + 2b_d-2,k-1   for  d ‚â• 3,

    and the generating function
    
    ‚àë_d=1^‚àû‚àë_k=0^‚àû b_d,k t^d s^k =
          t+t^2/1-2t-2t^2s.

  
  *  The number a_d of maximum
  independent sets of B(d,3) satisfies 


    
    a_1 = 1, 
            a_2 = 6,
    
            a_d = 2d a_d-1 + d(d-1)a_d-2   for  d ‚â• 3,

  and has exponential generating function
  
    ‚àë_d=1^‚àûa_d t^d/d! = t+t^2/1-2t-t^2.

Let T be a tree on n vertices, and w be a vertex of T. T is defined to have nearly even branching property at w (in short, T is NEB at w) as follows. If n=1, T is NEB at w.  If n‚â• 2, T is NEB at w if the following conditions are satisfied:


  (i) T(w) has exactly one odd component if n is even, and T(w) has no odd component if n is odd; and

  (ii) for each neighbor v of w in T, T_v(w) is NEB at v.

sentence:
[Orthogonal Matrix, Hadamard Matrices, Cretan Matrix]  
An orthogonal matrix , S= (s_ij) of order n, is square and has the modulus of all its entries ‚â§ 1, and satisfies SS^‚ä§ = œâ I_n for n = 1, 2, 4t.

An Hadamard matrix of order has entries ¬± 1  and satisfies
HH^‚ä§ = nI_n for n = 1, 2, 4t, t > 0 an integer. Any Hadamard matrix can be put into normalized form , that is having the first row and column all plus 1s using Hadamard equivalence operations: that is it can be written with a core.

A Cretan matrix , S,  of order v has entries with modulus ‚â§ 1 and at least one element in  each row and column  must be 1, and which satisfies SS^‚ä§ = œâ I_v. A Cretan(n; œÑ; œâ ) matrix, or CM(n; œÑ ; œâ) has œÑ levels or values for its entries.

For the purposes of this paper we will consider an SBIBD(v, k, Œª), B, to be a v √ó v matrix, with entries 0 and 1, k ones per row and column, and the inner product of distinct pairs of rows and/or columns to be Œª. [Orthogonality equation, radius equation(s), characteristic equation(s), weight]
Consider the matrix S= (s_ij) comprising  the variables x and y.

The matrix orthogonality equation 
  
    S^‚ä§S = SS^‚ä§ = œâ I_n

yields two types of equations: the n equations which arise from taking the inner product of each row/column with itself (which leads to the diagonal elements of œâ I_n being œâ) are called radius equation(s) , g(x,y)=œâ, and the n^2 -n equations, f(x,y)=0, which arise from taking inner products of distinct rows of S (which leads to the zero off diagonal elements of œâ I_n)  are called characteristic equation(s) . The orthogonality equation is ‚àë_j=1^n s_ij^2 =  œâ. œâ is called the weight of S.

sentence:
For all n,j,Œ≥‚àà‚Ñï_0, a Jacobi-Stirling set partition
of [n]_2 into Œ≥ zero blocks and j nonzero blocks is an ordinary
set partition of [n]_2 into j+Œ≥ blocks for which the following
conditions hold:



  * Œ≥ of our blocks, called the zero blocks , are
distinguishable, but all other blocks are indistinguishable.


  * The zero blocks may be empty, but all other blocks are nonempty.


  * The union of the zero blocks may not contain both copies of any number.


  * Each nonzero block contains both copies of the smallest number it
contains, but does not contain both copies of any other number.

sentence:

unbalanced Jacobi-Stirling permutation pair of length n is an ordered
pair (œÄ_1,œÄ_2) with œÄ_1‚àà S_n+2Œ≥-1 and œÄ_2‚àà
S_n for which the following hold.



  * œÄ_1 has 2Œ≥-1 more cycles than œÄ_2.


  * The cycle maxima of œÄ_1 which are less than n + 1 are exactly
the cycle maxima of œÄ_2.

sentence:
We say that a planar N-cluster  is
  regular when:
  
  
  * each region (including the external region E_0) is (up to a
    negligible set) a closed set which is equal to
    the closure of its interior points (and in the following we will assume that the
    Lebesgue representant of the regions E_i is always a closed set);
  
  * each region, but the external one E_0, is bounded;
  
  * the boundary of the cluster, defined by
    
    ‚àÇ = ‚ãÉ_k=1^N ‚àÇ E_k

    is the continuous embedding of a finite planar graph
    (i.e. there are a finite number of simple continuous curves which we will call
    edges which can only meet in their end-points which we
    will call vertices and the faces of the graph
    correspond to the connected components of the regions);
  
  * each vertex has order at least three (i.e. it coincides
    with at least three end-points of the edges).
  

  Notice that the perimeter of a region E_i of a regular cluster
   is the
  sum of the length of the edges of E_i. Moreover since each edge
  belongs to the boundary of exactly two regions, we have
  
    P() = 1/2‚àë_k=0^N P(E_k) =
      ‚àë_œÉ edge of ‚Ñì(œÉ)
      = ‚Ñã^1(‚àÇ).

sentence:
[stationary cluster]
  We say that a regular planar cluster = (E_1, ‚Ä¶, E_N) is stationary if it
  satisfies the following conditions:
  
  
  * 
    
    every edge
    
    
    is either a circular
    arc or a straight segment (which,
    in the following, we will identify with an arc of zero curvature);
  
  * in every vertex exactly three arcs meet, defining three
    equal angles of 120 degrees;
  
  * it is possible to associate a real number p_i (which we will
    call pressure ) to each region
    E_i of the cluster, so that p_0 = 0 and such that any arc between the regions E_i and E_j has curvature
    | p_i - p_j |
    (it is a straight segment if p_i=p_j) and the region with higher pressure
    is towards the side where the the arc is convex.
  

  In particular it follows that the sum of the signed curvatures of
  the three arcs meeting in a vertex is always zero.

sentence:
Let  be a graph, possibly with loops and multiple arcs between nodes, defined on n nodes, and let T be an unrooted binary tree, with all internal nodes of degree 3, and with n leaves.
An embedding œÄ of  into T is an injective mapping from the nodes of  to the leaves of T. To every pair of endpoints (u, v) of an arc in , there corresponds a unique path p(œÄ(u),œÄ(v)) in T, connecting leaves œÄ(u) and œÄ(v). Define the congestion of an embedding œÄ to be:

    (œÄ) = max_a  arc of T| { (u,v)  in  : p(œÄ(u),œÄ(v))  contains a }|,

where note we count a multiple arc only once in the formula. 
Here |¬∑| denotes the number of elements in a set.

The carving-width () of a graph  is the minimal congestion over all its embeddings into binary trees.
The carving-width of a cell-decomposition () is the carving-width of its dual graph. Finally, we define the carving-width of a 3-manifold M, denoted by (M), to be the minimal carving-width over all its generalised triangulations.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a graph, with adjacent arcs (u,v) and (v,w). A lifting of uvw consists of removing all arcs (u,v) and (v,w) from , and adding arc (u,w). An immersion of  is a graph  that can be obtained from  by a sequence of liftings, and arc and node removals.

  Equivalently,  is an immersion of  if there exists a mapping of the nodes of  to the nodes of  where every arc (u,v) is sent to a path from œÄ(u) to œÄ(v) in  such that distinct arcs in  lead to arc-disjoint paths in .

sentence:
Let S be a normal surface in a triangulation . Crushing the triangulation along S consists of the following three steps:


  * Cut  open along S, leading to a cell-decomposition with various cell types, presented in Collapse.

  * Collapse each copy of S to a point, using the quotient topology. This gives four types of cells: tetrahedra, 3-sided footballs , 4-sided footballs , and triangular purses (all illustrated in Collapse).

  * Flatten all non-tetrahedra cells to obtain a triangulation, i.e. flatten footballs into edges, and triangular purses into triangles as in Collapse. 

Conclude by separating tetrahedra joined by pinched vertices and edges.

diagonal tetrahedron with vertices the image under f of the following four points:

sentence:
A plane permutation on [n] is a pair ùî≠=(s,œÄ) where s=(s_i)_i=0^n-1

The permutation D_ùî≠ induced by the diagonal-pairs (cyclically), i.e.,¬†D_ùî≠(œÄ(s_i-1))=s_i for 0<i< n, and
D_ùî≠(œÄ(s_n-1))=s_0, is called the diagonal of ùî≠.

A set  of projective k-subspaces is a generator set with respect to co-k-subspaces (briefly, a k-generator set of k-subspaces), if the set ‚ãÉ of all points of the subspaces contained by  is a generator set with respect to co-k-subspaces. sentence: Let X be a finite set with v elements called points and ‚Ñ¨ be a set of subsets of X called blocks . The pair (X,‚Ñ¨) is said to be a simple (v,k,Œª) balanced incomplete block design (or a simple (v,k,Œª)‚ÄìBIBD for short) if all the blocks contain exactly k points and if every pair of distinct points is contained in exactly Œª blocks. It is also required that v > k ‚â• 2. Such a design is said symmetric , and denoted SBIBD, if the number of points is equal to the number of blocks, or equivalently, if the cardinal of the intersection of two blocks is constant <cit.>.

sentence:
Let v be a leaf of T and w be its father. 
Consider the following cases:


  *  If u‚â† v is a child of w,
  then |T_u| ‚â• 3.

  *  If T_w is just the edge wv,
  then the father of w, say y, has two children w and u, 
    where |T_u|‚â•3.

If Case¬†<ref> holds, we say that {v} is a
  remainder of T and that w is the generator 
  of {v}. 
If Case¬†<ref> holds we say that {v,w} is a 
  remainder of T and that y is its generator . 
We say that T is reminder free if it does not contain any remainder. 
We denote the set of remainders of T by R(T) and by G(R(T)) 
  the set of its generators.

sentence:
[Grosshans‚ÄìRota‚ÄìStein <cit.>]
  The elements (T_r|T_c) ‚àà(L^-|P^+) where 
  
  
  * T_r and T_c are tableaux of the same shape,
  
  * T_r is row strict with entries in [n],
  
  * T_c is column strict,
  
  form a basis for the free module (L^-|P^+). We will call
  such tableaux standard .

  In the expansion of (T|S) as a sum of standard tableaux
  ‚àë_i c_i(T_i|S_i) we have that the shape of each T_i is
  larger than or equal to the shape of T, in dominance
  order. Further, the content of every T_i is equal to the content
  of T and the content of every S_i is equal to the content of
  S.

Let P be a poset and n a positive integer.  The function g : P ‚Üí [n] is an n-Grundy coloring of P if the following three conditions hold.

A line segment E with endpoints in ‚Ñí_d is said to be a d-minimal segment if E ‚à©‚Ñí_d consists precisely of the endpoints of E.

sentence:
Let E be an oriented d-minimal edge with endpoints p and q. If p and q do not lie on a line through the origin, the edge E is said to be oriented counterclockwise (clockwise, respectively) if it has the induced orientation by the counterclockwise (clockwise, respectively) oriented triangle T with vertices at the origin, p, and q.
If p and q lie on a line that passes through the origin, then by convention, E is said to be both oriented counterclockwise and clockwise .

sentence: Let T_l and T_r be two minimal triangles with denominator d. The pair of triangles T_l and T_r are called similar neighbors if T_l is G-equivalent to T_l' and T_r is G-equivalent to T_r', where T_l' = Conv((1+t/d,1/d), (1+t/d, 0), (t/d, 1/d) ), T_r' = Conv((2+t/d,1/d), (2+t/d, 0), (1+t/d, 1/d) ) for some fixed integer t, where 1+t, 2+t and d are pairwise relatively prime, and 3+2t ‚â† 0 mod d.[When 3+2t = 0 mod d, T_l and T_r are actually G-equivalent, so we exclude this case.]

sentence:
Let S and S' be bounded subsets of ‚Ñù^2 with Œî-complex decompositions ùíØ and ùíØ', respectively, consisting entirely of 0-simplices (e.g., S= S_i where S_i is a vertex), and ‚Ñ±: (S, ùíØ) ‚Üí (S', ùíØ') is an equidecomposability relation. Recall that ‚Ñ± may be regarded as an assignment of G-maps g_i ‚àà G to the points S_i in ùíØ. We say that g_i ‚àà‚Ñ± if g_i is  assigned to some face in ùíØ. Then we define a maximal subcomplex M(g_i) for every g_i ‚àà‚Ñ± to be the set consisting of 0-simplices as follows,
    
    M(g_i) := {S_j|g_i acts on S_j sending to S_j' , S_j ‚ààùíØ S_j' ‚ààùíØ'}

    Furthermore, we define a maximal decomposition of ‚Ñ± as follows,
    
    ùíØ_M(‚Ñ±) := {M(g_i)|g_i‚àà ‚Ñ±}.

sentence: Let S and S' be bounded subsets of ‚Ñù^2 with some Œî-complex decompositions ùíØ and ùíØ', respectively, and suppose there exists an equidecomposability relation ‚Ñ±: (S, ùíØ) ‚Üí (S', ùíØ'). If every maximal subcomplex M(g_i) induced by this equidecomposability relation is a disconnected 0-simplex space, and S and S' are not a finite set of points, then this equidecomposability relation is called an intractable equidecomposability relation. Otherwise, it is referred to as tractable .

sentence:
Let T be a finite, rooted tree in which each internal node
has either one or two children.
To each internal node (which includes the root)
t ‚àà T, we associate a vertex p(t) ‚àà G.

We say that T is a matching tree if
the set of vertices p(t) fulfil the following two conditions.
For any node t_r ‚àà T, let (t_1, ‚Ä¶, t_r) be
the path from the root t_1 to t_r.
Then,


  * all p(t_1), ‚Ä¶, p(t_r) are distinct, and

  * { p(t)  |  t ‚àà{t_1, ‚Ä¶, t_r}‚à© V_m} forms an independent set in G,

where V_m denotes the set of nodes with one child.

 Let G be a planar circular network with boundary set V, partitioned into the subsets of boundary sources A and boundary sinks B. There is a matrix M with rows indexed by A and columns indexed by V, called the boundary measurement matrix , such that

sentence: To a checkerboard-colored link diagram D, we construct the associated Tait graph G as follows. First, we associate a vertex to each black region of D. Next, we join a pair of distinct vertices by an edge if the two corresponding regions share a crossing of D and we join a vertex to itself if the corresponding region meets a crossing of D twice. Finally, we label the edges with either + or - according to the convention displayed in the center of Figure¬†<ref>. What results is an edge-signed planar graph G called the Tait graph associated to D. See Figure¬†<ref> for an example of the construction of a Tait graph. Note that the white regions of D correspond to the faces (complementary regions) of G. Also note that changing the crossing type of a single crossing of D corresponds to changing the sign of the corresponding edge of G and forming the mirror reflection D of D corresponds to changing all of the edge signs of G.

sentence: Let G be a graph. An edge of G is called a loop if it joins a vertex to itself. An edge e={v,w} of G is called a multiedge if there are multiple parallel edges of G that join vertex v to vertex w. An edge of G is called a bridge if deleting this edge from G increases the number of connected components. A vertex of G is called a cut vertex if deleting this vertex and its incident edges from G increases the number of connected components. A graph G is called nonseparable if it is connected and contains no cut vertices. Every graph G can be decomposed into blocks , where a block is either an isolated vertex of G, a bridge of G with its incident vertices, a loop of G with its incident vertex, or a maximally connected subgraph of G that contains no cut vertices and is neither a bridge nor a loop of G. The blocks and cut vertices of a connected graph G give rise to a block decomposition of G as G=G_1‚à® G_2‚à®‚ãØ‚à® G_k, where the G_i are the blocks of G and where the G_i meet at shared cut vertices of G.

sentence: Let G be a graph. Then, for e an edge of G, we use G-e to denote the graph obtained from G by deleting the edge e and G/e to denote the graph obtained from G by contracting the edge e. Our convention will be that contracting a loop is the same as deleting the loop. Let H ‚äÜ E(G) denote a subset of the edges of G. Then we use G|H to denote G restricted to the edges of H, that is, G|H is the (spanning) subgraph of G whose vertices are the same as those of G and whose edges are the edges of H. Alternatively, G|H is the graph obtained from G by deleting the edges in the complement H=E(G)-H of the edge set H. Finally, let G/H denote the graph obtained from G by contracting the edges of H.

sentence:
The Tutte polynomial of a graph G, denoted œá_G(x, y), is a two-variable polynomial invariant defined recursively as follows. 

	
  (1) If G=G_1‚äî G_2‚äî‚ãØ‚äî G_k is a disjoint union of k graphs, then 
    œá_G(x,y)=œá_G_1(x,y)¬∑œá_G_2(x,y)‚ãØœá_G_k(x,y).
  
	
  (2) If G=G_1‚à® G_2‚à®‚ãØ‚à® G_k is a block decomposition of a connected graph G into k blocks, then 
    œá_G(x,y)=œá_G_1(x,y)¬∑œá_G_2(x,y)‚ãØœá_G_k(x,y).
 
  
  (3) If G is nonseparable, then 
    œá_G(x, y)={[                                        1                   if G contains no edges;                           x ¬∑œá_G/e(x, y)                    if e is a bridge of G;                           y ¬∑œá_G-e(x, y)                      if e is a loop of G;                  œá_G/e(x, y)+œá_G-e(x, y) if e is neither a bridge nor a loop of G;                                          ].

sentence: The planar dual of a planar graph G, denoted G^*, is the planar graph where the vertices of G^* correspond to the faces of G, the faces of G^* correspond to the vertices of G, and the edges of G^* correspond to the edges of G so that an edge and its planar dual intersect transversely when we overlay G with its planar dual G^*.

sentence: Let D be a link diagram. We may either A-resolve or B-resolve a crossing of D according to Figure¬†<ref>. A state œÉ of D is a choice of A- or B-resolution at each crossing. Given a state œÉ of D, the corresponding dual state , denoted œÉ^*, is the state where the choices of A- and B-resolution from the state œÉ are all reversed. The all-A (resp. all-B) state of D, denoted œÉ_A (resp. œÉ_B), is the state that results from choosing the A-resolution (resp. B-resolution) at each crossing of D. Note that œÉ_A and œÉ_B are dual states.

sentence: By resolving the crossings of a link diagram D according to a state œÉ, we form the trivalent state graph H_œÉ that consists of a disjoint collection of state circles and a disjoint collection of state segments (either A-segments or B-segments ) that are used to record the locations and types of the crossing resolutions. Let H_A (resp. H_B) denote the state graph that arises from the all-A (resp. all-B) state. For an example of a link diagram and its all-A state graph, see Figure¬†<ref>. Note that we may sometimes suppress the labels of A and B on the state segments of H_œÉ.

sentence: A link diagram D is called œÉ-adequate with respect to a state œÉ if its state graph H_œÉ contains no state segments that connect a state circle to itself. We call such a state a œÉ-adequate state of D. As a special case, D is called A-adequate (resp. B-adequate ) if H_A (resp. H_B) contains no state state segments that connect a state circle to itself and D is called semi-adequate if it is either A- or B-adequate. For an example of an A-adequate link diagram, see Figure¬†<ref>. Note that D is A-adequate if and only if its mirror reflection D is B-adequate.

sentence:
A ribbon graph ùîæ is a surface with boundary that consists of a vertex set V(ùîæ) and an edge set E(ùîæ), where the vertices are a collection of disks, where the edges are a collection of bands, and where the following conditions hold. 

	
  * The vertices and edges intersect in a disjoint collection of line segments.
	
  * Each such line segment is formed by the intersection of one vertex and one edge. 
	
  * Each edge contains exactly two such line segments. 

To distinguish ribbon graphs from graphs, we will often use the term vertex disk instead of vertex and edge ribbon instead of edge. For examples of ribbon graphs, see Figure¬†<ref> and Figure¬†<ref>.

sentence: Given a state œÉ of a link diagram D, we construct the corresponding state ribbon graph ùîæ_œÉ as follows. Recall that, by Definition¬†<ref>, we can use the state œÉ to construct the state graph H_œÉ, which consists of a disjoint collection of state circles and a disjoint collection of state segments. By capping off each state circle of H_œÉ with a disk (in such a way that disks coming from inner circles lie above disks coming from outer circles), we obtain the disjoint collection of vertex disks of ùîæ_œÉ. By covering each state segment of H_œÉ with a planar band that deformation retracts back to the state segment, we obtain the collection of edge ribbons of ùîæ_œÉ. It can quickly be seen that the conditions required by Definition¬†<ref> are satisfied.

We define a graded associative algebra U_r by quiver and relations, over any field k.
The quiver Q has vertices

    { e_x |  x ‚àà‚Ñ§^r },

and arrows

The arrow a_x,i is directed from e_x to e_x+œµ_i, and
b_x,i is directed from e_x to e_x-œµ_i.  
U_r is defined to be the path algebra kQ of Q,
modulo square relations ,

    *(U0)
    a_x,i a_x + œµ_i,i = 0,
    
    b_x,i b_x - œµ_i,i = 0,



for x ‚àà‚Ñ§^r,  1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ r, as well as supercommutation relations ,

    *(U1)
    a_x,i a_x + œµ_i,j + a_x,j a_x + œµ_j,i = 0,
    
    b_x,i b_x - œµ_i,j + b_x,j b_x - œµ_j,i = 0,

for x ‚àà‚Ñ§^r,  1 ‚â§ i,j‚â§ r,  i‚â† j, and Heisenberg relations ,

    b_x,i+1 a_x- œµ_i+1,i+1 + a_x,i+1 b_x + œµ_i+1,i+1,



for x ‚àà‚Ñ§^r,  1 ‚â§ i < r.

sentence: Consider an n-sided regular polygon with nodes placed at each of the vertices, the midpoints of each side, and the center of the polygon.  Then, a magic polygon is an n-sided regular polygon containing an arrangement of the numbers 1 to 2n+1 within this arrangement of nodes such that the sum of the three nodes on each side and the sum of the three nodes on each diagonal are equal.  This sum is called the magic sum .

sentence:
Let T_1 and T_2 be two trees in .  A support is a pair of partitions (A,B) where A = (A_0, A_1, ..., A_k) is a partition of ( E(T_1) ‚à™ C(T_1)) ‚à© E(T_2) and B = (B_0, B_1, ..., B_k) is a partition of ( E(T_2) ‚à™ C(T_2) ) ‚à© E(T_1) such that:


  * A_0 = B_0 contain all edges corresponding to splits that are shared by the two trees or exist in one tree and are compatible with the other tree.  That is, 

    A_0 = B_0 = (E(T_1) ‚à© E(T_2)) 
         ‚à™( E(T_1) ‚à© C(T_2) )
         ‚à™( C(T_1) ‚à© E(T_2) ).


  * A_i is compatible with B_j for all 1 ‚â§ j < i ‚â§ k.

A pair (A_i, B_i) for 0 ‚â§ i ‚â§ k is called a support pair .

A contact between P and T is a maximal subpath S of P containing at
least one edge such that S is also a subtrail of T i.e., for 
0‚â§ i < j ‚â§ r, we say that (x_i,e_i+1,x_i+1, ‚Ä¶, e_j, x_j) is a contact
between P and T if (x_i,e_i+1,x_i+1, ‚Ä¶, e_j, x_j) is a subtrail of T, but
neither (x_i-1,e_i,x_i, ‚Ä¶ e_j, x_j) (if i > 0) nor (x_i,e_i+1,x_i+1,
‚Ä¶, x_j, e_j+1, x_j+1) (if j < r) is a subtrail of T. 

    Define  (P,T) = |{(i,j): 0 ‚â§ i < j ‚â§ r,    
    (x_i,e_i+1,x_i+1, ‚Ä¶, e_j, x_j)

sentence:
A v-star in G is a subgraph of G
consisting of a set of edges incident with a common vertex v
(see Figure¬†<ref>(a)). Denote by S_v^i a star
consisting of i edges incident with v. A v-star S_v^i is
saturated (respectively, a trivial) if i=d(v)
(respectively, i=1). A v-wing in G is a K_3 in
which only d_G(v)>2, and we call v the stalk vertex of
the wing  (see Figure¬†<ref>(b)). A 3-wing is
a v-wing with d(v)=3. A semiwing is a K_3 with exactly one
vertex of degree 2 in G (see Figure¬†<ref>(c)). In
a semiwing, the stalk vertices are the vertices with degree
greater than 2. Let w_v(ùí´) denote the number of
3-cliques in ùí´ which are induced by v-wings. Let
V_3w be the set of stalk vertices of the 3-wings in G.

sentence: <cit.> A coloring of a graph is an assignment of colors to its vertices so that no two adjacent vertices have the same color. The set of all vertices with any one color is independent and is called a color class. An n-coloring of a graph G uses n colors; it thereby partitions V into n color classes. The chromatic number œá(G) is defined as the minimum n for which G has an n - coloring. A graph G is n-colorable if œá(G)‚â§ n and is n-chromatic if œá(G)=n.

sentence: <cit.> An edge-coloring or line-coloring of a graph G is an assignment of colors to its edges (lines) so that no two adjacent edges (lines) are assigned the same color. An n-edge-coloring  of G is an edge-coloring of G which uses exactly n colors. The edge-chromatic number œá'(G) is the minimum n for which G has an n-edge-coloring.

So we have the following n√ó m array satisfying t_i,j‚â• t_i+1,j‚â• 0 and t_i,j‚â• t_i,j+1‚â• 0.


[ t_1,1 t_1,2 t_1,3     ‚ãØ t_1,m; t_2,1 t_2,2 t_2,3       t_2,m;     ‚ãÆ                       ‚ãÆ; t_n,1 t_n,2 t_n,3     ‚ãØ t_n,m;       ]

sentence:
A plane partition œÄ is a finite set of positive integer lattice points (i,j,k) such that if (i,j,k)‚ààœÄ and 1‚â§ i'‚â§ i, 1‚â§ j'‚â§ j, and 1‚â§ k'‚â§ k then (i',j',k')‚ààœÄ.

A plane partition œÄ is symmetric if whenever (i,j,k)‚ààœÄ then (j,i,k)‚ààœÄ as well. œÄ is cyclically symmetric if whenever (i,j,k)‚ààœÄ then (j,k,i) and (k,i,j) are in œÄ as well. 
A plane partition is totally symmetric if 
it is both symmetric and cyclically symmetric, so that  
whenever (i,j,k)‚ààœÄ then all six permutations of (i,j,k) are also in œÄ.

 A plane partition is self-complementary inside a given bounding box a√ó b√ó c if it is equal to its complement in the box, that is, the collection of empty cubes in the box is of the same shape as the collection of cubes in the plane partition itself.  
A totally symmetric self-complementary plane partition (TSSCPP) inside a 
2n √ó 2n √ó 2n box is a plane partition which is both totally symmetric and self-complementary inside the box.

sentence:
[GAPs]  Let G be an additive group.  A symmetric generalized arithmetic progression in G, or symmetric GAP for short, is a quadruplet = (Q, N, v, d), where the rank () = d is a non-negative integer, the dimensions N = (N_1,‚Ä¶,N_d) are a d-tuple of positive reals, the steps v = (v_1,‚Ä¶,v_d) are a d-tuple of elements of G, and Q ‚äÇ G is the set

    Q = {‚àë_i=1^d n_i v_i: n_i ‚àà [-N_i,N_i] ‚àÄ i =1,‚Ä¶,d},

where [a,b] denotes the set of integers between a and b inclusive.
We shall often abuse notation and write Q for .  For any t > 0, we define the dilate _t of  to be the GAP _t := (Q_t, t N, v, d) formed by dilating all the dimensions by t.   We say that  is proper if all the elements n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_d v_d for n_i ‚àà [-N_i,N_i] are distinct.   We say that Q is t-proper if tQ is proper.

We define the volume of  to be vol() := ‚àè_i=1^d (2 ‚åä N_i ‚åã + 1).  Note that |Q| ‚â§vol(), with equality if and only if  is proper.

sentence:
The Cover Game [h,k]G,Œº is a game between two players, 
and , on a bipartite graph G. At each step i of the game the players maintain an [h,k] F_i in G. 
At step i+1 can 


  * remove a connected component from F_i, or

  * if the number of connected components of F_i is strictly less than Œº, pick a vertex and challenge to find another [h,k] F_i+1 in G
such that


  * F_i+1 extends F_i.  That is, each connected component of F_i is also a connected component of F_i+1;

  * F_i+1 covers the vertex picked by .


loses the game [h,k]G,Œº if at some point she cannot answer a challenge by .  Otherwise, wins.

sentence:
[Admissible random walks and lattice paths]
  Let (S_k)_0‚â§ k ‚â§ n be a simple symmetric random walk on
  _0 or  of length n starting at 0. That is, we have
  (S_0=0) = 1 as well as
  
    (S_k=j-1| S_k-1=j)=(S_k=j+1 |
        S_k-1=j)   =1/2     for j‚â• 1,
    (S_k = 1 | S_k-1=0)     = 1,

  for random walks defined on _0, and
  
    (S_k=j-1| S_k-1=j)=(S_k=j+1|
      S_k-1=j)=1/2     for  j‚àà

  for random walks on . Then (S_k)_0‚â§ k‚â§ n is said to
  be admissible of height h, if the random walk stays
  within the interval [0, h] and ends in h, i.e. S_k‚àà [0,h]
  for all 0‚â§ k‚â§ n and (S_n = h) = 1. It is called
  admissible , if it is admissible of any height h ‚àà.

  The probability that a random walk of length n is admissible of
  height h is written as p_n^(h) and q_n^(h) for
  random walks on _0 and , respectively. Furthermore, the
  probabilities that a random walk is admissible at all are defined as
  p_n := ‚àë_h‚â• 0 p_n^(h) and q_n := ‚àë_h‚â• 0
  q_n^(h) respectively.

  Finally, an admissible lattice path is a sequence of integers
  realizing an admissible random walk.

sentence:
[The multiplicity matrix]
Let Œî =  {œÉ_1, œÉ_2, ‚Ä¶, œÉ_r } be a nonempty d-complex on {1,2,‚Ä¶, n } and let 
S =  {œÑ_1, œÑ_2, ‚Ä¶, œÑ_l } be a nonempty collection of multisets on {1,2,‚Ä¶, n }, both ordered in lexicographic order unless specified otherwise. 
The multiplicity matrix M(Œî,S) is the l √ó r matrix 

    M(Œî,S) 
    =
    [ m(œÑ_1 ‚äÜœÉ_1) m(œÑ_1 ‚äÜœÉ_2)           ‚Ä¶ m(œÑ_1 ‚äÜœÉ_r); m(œÑ_2 ‚äÜœÉ_1) m(œÑ_2 ‚äÜœÉ_2)           ‚Ä¶ m(œÑ_2 ‚äÜœÉ_r);           ‚ãÆ           ‚ãÆ           ‚ã±           ‚ãÆ; m(œÑ_l ‚äÜœÉ_1) m(œÑ_l ‚äÜœÉ_2)           ‚Ä¶ m(œÑ_l ‚äÜœÉ_r) ]
    =
    [ œÑ_1(œÉ_1) œÑ_1(œÉ_2)        ‚Ä¶ œÑ_1(œÉ_r); œÑ_2(œÉ_1) œÑ_2(œÉ_2)        ‚Ä¶ œÑ_2(œÉ_r);        ‚ãÆ        ‚ãÆ        ‚ã±        ‚ãÆ; œÑ_l(œÉ_1) œÑ_l(œÉ_2)        ‚Ä¶ œÑ_l(œÉ_r) ]
    
    =     ¬†   œÉ_1    ‚ãØ   œÉ_r œÑ_1     m(œÑ_1 ‚äÜœÉ_1)    ‚ãØ    m(œÑ_1 ‚äÜœÉ_r) ‚ãÆ   ‚ãÆ   ‚ã±   ‚ãÆœÑ_l      m(œÑ_l ‚äÜœÉ_1)    ‚ãØ    m(œÑ_l ‚äÜœÉ_r) 
    =     ¬†   œÉ_1    ‚ãØ   œÉ_r œÑ_1    œÑ_1(œÉ_1)    ‚ãØ   œÑ_1(œÉ_r) ‚ãÆ   ‚ãÆ   ‚ã±   ‚ãÆœÑ_l    œÑ_l(œÉ_1)    ‚ãØ   œÑ_l(œÉ_r)

whose entry in the i-th row and j-th column is M(Œî,S)_ij = m(œÑ_i ‚äÜœÉ_j).
If we take S to be the collection of all multisets of cardinality at most d on {1,2,‚Ä¶, n }, then by definition, for any ring R the kernel of the matrix M(Œî,S) in R^r is the R-submodule of R-balancings of Œî.
By Theorem¬†<ref>, over any characteristic zero domain R, the kernel of the matrix M(Œî,Œî_n,d-1) in R^r is precisely the R-submodule of R-balancings of Œî.

We shall say that a property P has supersaturable complement if there exists a function I_Pùîê(‚Ñù^d)‚Üí[0,+‚àû] which satisfies the following seven axioms:


  * There exists ùî™(P)>0 such that if d(A)>ùî™(P) then P(A)=1.

  * There exists r>0 such that if all points of A_1 are at least distance r away from all points of A_2, then I_P(A_1‚à™ A_2) ‚â• I_P(A_1)+I_P(A_2) and P(A_1 ‚à™ A_2)=max{P(A_1),P(A_2)}.

  * There exist Œµ>0 and a strictly positive function f  (0,+‚àû)‚Üí‚Ñù such that if the set

    {x ‚àà‚Ñù^d  m(Q(x,Œ¥)‚à© A)>(1-Œµ)m(Q(x,Œ¥))}

has property P, then I_P(A)‚â• f(Œ¥).

Let _2^ be the additive group _2^ := { (x_i)_i ‚àà: x_i ‚àà_2  for all  i ‚àà}, where _2 is the field of two elements, and let (_2^)_0 be the finitely generated subgroup of _2^ consisting of those sequences (x_i)_i ‚àà with at most finitely many x_i non-zero. sentence:
Let G = (G,¬∑) be a group and l ‚â• 0 be an integer.  For each 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l, let r_i ‚â• 0 be an integer, let H_i,0 = (H_i,0,+) be a finite abelian group, and let H_i,j := {-N_i,j,‚Ä¶,N_i,j} for 1 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i be intervals.  Suppose we have maps œï_i,j: H_i,j‚Üí G for 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i obeying the following properties, where we abbreviate

    A_i := œï_i,0(H_i,0) ¬∑‚Ä¶¬∑œï_i,r_i(H_i,r_i);    A_‚â• i := A_l¬∑‚Ä¶¬∑ A_i



  * For all 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l and 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i, we have 

    œï_i,j(0) = 1.


  * For any 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l, 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i, and n, n' ‚àà H_i,j with n+n' ‚àà H_i,j, we have

    œï_i,j(n) œï_i,j(n') ‚àà A_‚â• i+1¬∑œï_i,j(n+n').


  * For any 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l, 0 ‚â§ j,j' ‚â§ r_i, n ‚àà H_i,j, and n' ‚àà H_i,j', we have

    [œï_i,j(n), œï_i,j'(n')] ‚àà A_‚â• i+1.


  * For any 1 ‚â§ i' < i ‚â§ l, 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i, 0 ‚â§ j' ‚â§ r_i', n ‚àà H_i,j, and n' ‚àà H_i',j', we have

    [œï_i',j'(n'), œï_i,j(n)] ‚àà A_‚â• i+1¬∑œï_i,0(H_i,0) ¬∑‚Ä¶¬∑œï_i,max(j-1,0)(H_i,max(j-1,0)).


Then we refer to the multiplicative set 

    (A_‚â• 1, G) = ( ‚àè_i=l^1 ‚àè_j=0^r_iœï_i,j(H_i,j), G)

as a coset nilprogression of derived length l, ranks r_1,‚Ä¶,r_l, and volume ‚àè_i=1^l ‚àè_j=0^r_i |H_i,j|.  (If l=0, we adopt the convention that A_‚â• 1 = {1}.)

If the groups H_i,0 and maps œï_i,0 are trivial, we refer to the coset nilprogression simply as a nilprogression .

Let K ‚â• 1.  A K-approximate group is a centred set (A,G) such that there exists a set X ‚äÇ G with |X| ‚â§ K such that A^2 ‚äÇ X ¬∑ A ‚äÇ A ¬∑ X ¬∑ X and A^2 ‚äÇ A ¬∑ X ‚äÇ X ¬∑ X ¬∑ A.  Note that this in particular implies that

sentence:
A (symmetric) generalised arithmetic progression (or progression for short) in an abelian group G = (G,+) is any set P of the form

    P = { n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_r v_r: n_i ‚àà, |n_i| ‚â§ N_i  for all  1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ r }

for some v_1,‚Ä¶,v_r ‚àà and N_1,‚Ä¶,N_r ‚â• 1.  We refer to r as the rank of the progression.  If t ‚â• 1, we say that the progression P is t-proper if the sums

    n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_r v_r

for n_i ‚àà, |n_i| ‚â§ tN_i are all distinct.  We say that a progression is proper if it is 1-proper.

sentence:

sentence:
[Freiman's theorem for the lamplighter group]  Let (A, ‚ãâ_2^) be a multiplicative set of doubling constant at most K for some K ‚â• 1.  Then A is O_K(1)-controlled by a set B which is of one of the following forms:


  (Case 1) B = {0}√ó V for some finite-dimensional subspace V of _2^.

  (Case 2) B = { (n,œï(n)+v): n ‚àà P, v ‚àà V }, where V is a T^d-invariant finite-dimensional subspace of _2^ for some d ‚â• 1, P ‚äÇ d is a generalised arithmetic progression of rank O_K(1), and œï: P ‚Üí_2^ is a function whose graph n ‚Ü¶ (n,œï(n)) Freiman isomorphism modulo V in the sense that

    (n_1,œï(n_1)) ¬∑ (n_2,œï(n_2)) = (n_3,œï(n_3)) ¬∑ (n_4,œï(n_4))  mod  V
 
whenever n_1,n_2,n_3,n_4 ‚àà P are such that n_1+n_2=n_3+n_4. 

If A ‚äÇ‚ãâ (_2^)_0, then one can take V to be a finite-dimensional subspace of (_2^)_0 in Case 1, and can take V to be trivial in Case 2.

sentence: [K-control]  Let K ‚â• 1.  A multiplicative set (A,G) is said to be K-controlled by another multiplicative set (B,G') if G' is a subgroup of G, if |B| ‚â§ K |A|, and there exists another finite non-empty subset X of G with |X| ‚â§ K such that A ‚äÇ (X ¬∑ B) ‚à© (B ¬∑ X).

sentence:
[Lamplighter group]  Let _2^ be the additive group _2^ := { (x_i)_i ‚àà: x_i ‚àà_2  for all  i ‚àà}, where _2 is the field of two elements, and let (_2^)_0 be the finitely generated subgroup of _2^ consisting of those sequences (x_i)_i ‚àà with at most finitely many x_i non-zero.  Let T: _2^‚Üí_2^ be the shift automorphism T(x_i)_i ‚àà := (x_i-1)_i ‚àà; this preserves (_2^)_0. The extended lamplighter group ‚ãâ_2^ is the set { (n, x): n ‚àà, x ‚àà_2^} with the group law

    (n, x) ¬∑ (n',x') := (n+n', T^n'(x) + x').

The lamplighter group ‚ãâ (_2^)_0 is the subgroup of ‚ãâ_2^ in which the second coordinate lies in (_2^)_0.

sentence: [Totally torsion-free solvable group]  Let G = (G,¬∑) be a group.  The derived series G^(0)‚â• G^(1)‚â•‚Ä¶ of G is formed by setting G^(0) := G and G^(i+1) := [G^(i),G^(i)] for i=0,1,‚Ä¶; observe that these are normal subgroups of G.  A group is solvable if G^(l+1) is trivial for some l, known as the derived length of G.  A group G is torsion-free if every non-identity element in G has infinite order (thus if a ‚àà G and a^n=1 for some non-zero n, then a=1).  A solvable group G is totally torsion-free if G/G^(i) is torsion-free for every i.

sentence:
[Coset nilprogression]  Let G = (G,¬∑) be a group and l ‚â• 0 be an integer.  For each 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l, let r_i ‚â• 0 be an integer, let H_i,0 = (H_i,0,+) be a finite abelian group, and let H_i,j := {-N_i,j,‚Ä¶,N_i,j} for 1 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i be intervals.  Suppose we have maps œï_i,j: H_i,j‚Üí G for 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i obeying the following properties, where we abbreviate

    A_i := œï_i,0(H_i,0) ¬∑‚Ä¶¬∑œï_i,r_i(H_i,r_i);    A_‚â• i := A_l¬∑‚Ä¶¬∑ A_i



  * For all 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l and 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i, we have 

    œï_i,j(0) = 1.


  * For any 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l, 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i, and n, n' ‚àà H_i,j with n+n' ‚àà H_i,j, we have

    œï_i,j(n) œï_i,j(n') ‚àà A_‚â• i+1¬∑œï_i,j(n+n').


  * For any 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ l, 0 ‚â§ j,j' ‚â§ r_i, n ‚àà H_i,j, and n' ‚àà H_i,j', we have

    [œï_i,j(n), œï_i,j'(n')] ‚àà A_‚â• i+1.


  * For any 1 ‚â§ i' < i ‚â§ l, 0 ‚â§ j ‚â§ r_i, 0 ‚â§ j' ‚â§ r_i', n ‚àà H_i,j, and n' ‚àà H_i',j', we have

    [œï_i',j'(n'), œï_i,j(n)] ‚àà A_‚â• i+1¬∑œï_i,0(H_i,0) ¬∑‚Ä¶¬∑œï_i,max(j-1,0)(H_i,max(j-1,0)).


Then we refer to the multiplicative set 

    (A_‚â• 1, G) = ( ‚àè_i=l^1 ‚àè_j=0^r_iœï_i,j(H_i,j), G)

as a coset nilprogression of derived length l, ranks r_1,‚Ä¶,r_l, and volume ‚àè_i=1^l ‚àè_j=0^r_i |H_i,j|.  (If l=0, we adopt the convention that A_‚â• 1 = {1}.)

If the groups H_i,0 and maps œï_i,0 are trivial, we refer to the coset nilprogression simply as a nilprogression .

sentence: [Centred set] A centred set in G is a multiplicative set (A,G) that contains the group identity 1 (thus in particular A^k ‚äÇ A^k' for k ‚â§ k') and is also symmetric (thus A^-1 := {a^-1: a ‚àà A } is equal to A).

sentence:
[K-approximate group]  Let K ‚â• 1.  A K-approximate group is a centred set (A,G) such that there exists a set X ‚äÇ G with |X| ‚â§ K such that A^2 ‚äÇ X ¬∑ A ‚äÇ A ¬∑ X ¬∑ X and A^2 ‚äÇ A ¬∑ X ‚äÇ X ¬∑ X ¬∑ A.  Note that this in particular implies that

    |A^k| ‚â§ K^k-1 |A|

for all k ‚â• 1.

sentence:
[Generalised arithmetic progression]  A (symmetric) generalised arithmetic progression (or progression for short) in an abelian group G = (G,+) is any set P of the form

    P = { n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_r v_r: n_i ‚àà, |n_i| ‚â§ N_i  for all  1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ r }

for some v_1,‚Ä¶,v_r ‚àà and N_1,‚Ä¶,N_r ‚â• 1.  We refer to r as the rank of the progression.  If t ‚â• 1, we say that the progression P is t-proper if the sums

    n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_r v_r

for n_i ‚àà, |n_i| ‚â§ tN_i are all distinct.  We say that a progression is proper if it is 1-proper.

sentence:
[Coset progression]  A (symmetric) coset progression in an abelian group G = (G,+) is any set of the form H+P, where H is a finite subgroup H of G, and P is a generalised arithmetic progression

    P = { n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_r v_r: n_i ‚àà, |n_i| ‚â§ N_i  for all  1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ r }.

We refer to r as the rank of the coset progression.  If t ‚â• 1, we say that the coset progression H+P is t-proper if the sums

    h + n_1 v_1 + ‚Ä¶ + n_r v_r

for h ‚àà H, n_i ‚àà, |n_i| ‚â§ tN_i are all distinct.  We say that a coset progression is proper if it is 1-proper.

  (G,f_E) has the odd cycle property if every cycle of odd
  length in G, with edges e_1,‚Ä¶,e_2k+1, satisfies
  
    d/2‚àë_l=1^2k+1f_E(e_l) ‚â° 0d.

sentence:
Let (G,f_E) be an e-labeled graph. We say that (G,f_E) is
  compatible if the following conditions hold
  
  
  * d is odd and (G,f_E) has the even cycle property.
  
  * d is even and (G,f_E) has both the even and the odd cycle
    properties.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph and let C be any cycle of G. We
  associate a vector œâ_C ‚àà^|E| with C. We index the
  coordinates of œâ_C using the edges of G.
  
  Label the consecutive edges of C
  
    e_1,e_2,‚Ä¶,e_k-1,e_k,

  with e_1 any edge of the cycle.
  If C is an even cycle, we adjoin (-1)^i to e_i:
  
    e_1,-e_2,‚Ä¶,(-1)^i e_i,‚Ä¶,e_k-1,-e_k.

  If C is an odd cycle and d is even, we adjoin d/2 to each edge:
  
    d/2 e_1,‚Ä¶,d/2  e_i,‚Ä¶,d/2 e_k.

  
  Since C need not be a simple cycle, some edges may appear more
  than once in¬†(<ref>). Let e'_1,‚Ä¶,e'_r be the
  distinct edges of C. For each distinct edge e'_i, we
  define œâ_e'_i to be the sum of the numbers adjoined to each
  appearance of e'_i in¬†(<ref>)
  or¬†(<ref>). For example, if an edge e'_i appears
  twice, both times accompanied by a 1, then the corresponding
  œâ_e'_i is 2. If one of the appearances has a 1 and the other
  one a (-1), then œâ_e'_i is 0.

  Given a cycle C, we define œâ_C as
  
    (œâ_C)_(u,v) =
        œâ_(u,v)   if (u,v) is in C,
    
          0    otherwise.


  Notice that in¬†(<ref>), the choice of e_1 may
  swap the 1's and the -1's. This is not problematic, since it
  only changes œâ_C into -œâ_C. The œâ_C, with C
  of even length, are in the kernel of the incidence matrix of G and
  we only use them in that context.

sentence: If a symmetric function f‚ààŒõ can be written as a non-negative linear combination of Schur functions then we say that f is Schur positive . If f can be written as a non-positive linear combination of Schur functions then we say that f is Schur negative . If f is neither Schur positive or Schur negative then we say that f is Schur incomparable .

sentence:
[ACA]
Let r be a non-negative integer and let W=(w_j)_j‚àà[-r,r]^n be an n-dimensional array of integers of size (2r+1)^n. The additive cellular automaton (ACA for short) over m associated with W is the map ‚àÇ which assigns, to every n-dimensional infinite array of m, a new array by a linear transformation whose coefficients are those of W. More precisely, the map ‚àÇ is defined by

    ‚àÇ( (a_i)_i‚àà^n) = (‚àë_j‚àà[-r,r]^nw_ja_i+j)_i‚àà^n,

for all arrays (a_i)_i‚àà^n of elements in m. We say that ‚àÇ is of dimension n‚â•1 and of weight W with radius r‚â•0.

sentence:
[Balanced multisets of m]
A multiset of m is said to be balanced if it contains all the elements of m with the same multiplicity, i.e., if its associated multiplicity function _M is constant on m, equal to 1/m|M|.

Let n and m be positive integers. Let A=(a_i)_i‚àà^n be an array of m. The array A is said to be arithmetic with first element a and with common difference d=(d_1,‚Ä¶,d_n)‚àà(m)^n if

for all i=(i_1,‚Ä¶,i_n)‚àà^n. The arithmetic array with first element a‚ààm and with common difference d‚àà(m)^n is denoted by (a,d). The arithmetic simplex of size s, with first element a‚ààm and with common difference d=(d_1,‚Ä¶,d_n)‚àà(m)^n, is the simplex (0_^n,+‚ãØ+,s) appearing in the array (a,d)=(a_i)_i‚àà^n and is denoted by (a,d,s), that is,

    (a,d,s) = { a + i_1d_1 + ‚ãØ + i_nd_n | i‚àà^n such that i_1+‚ãØ+i_n‚â§ s-1}.

For n=1, the arithmetic progression (a,d,s) is also denoted by (a,d,s).

Let A=(a_i)_i‚àà^n be an infinite array of elements in m and let (j,Œµ,s) be the n-simplex of size s, with orientation Œµ‚àà{-1,1}^n and whose principal vertex is a_j in A, that is,

Let u and v be two integers such that 0‚â§ u<v‚â§ n. The simplex (j,Œµ,s) is said to be (u,v)-antisymmetric if all its subsequences in the same direction of the edge between the vertices _u and _v are antisymmetric. More precisely, (j,Œµ,s) is (0,v)-antisymmetric if we have

    a_j+Œµ¬∑ k + a_j+Œµ¬∑ s(k) = 0, where  s(k) = (k_1,‚Ä¶,k_v-1,s-1-‚àë_l=1^nk_l,k_v+1,‚Ä¶,k_n),

    a_j+Œµ¬∑ k + a_j+Œµ¬∑ t(k) = 0, where (t(k))_l = k_œÑ(l) for all l‚àà[1,n],

where œÑ is the transposition (u,v), for all k‚àà^n such that k_1+‚ãØ+k_n‚â§ s-1.

sentence:
Let a‚â• 0, b‚â• 0, and s‚â• 1 be integers and let (s,a,b) be the graph obtained from K_s ‚à™Ãá (K_a ‚ñ° P_b) by adding every possible edge between the disjoint copy of K_s and a copy of K_a in K_a ‚ñ° P_b whose vertices have minimum degree. If either a=0 or b=0, then (s,a,b)‚âÉ K_s.
A path edge of (s,a,b) is an edge that belongs to one of the copies of P_b; a complete edge is an edge that belongs to one of the copies of K_a, or to K_s; a cross edge is an edge between K_s and K_a ‚ñ° P_b. The vertices in K_s and K_a that are incident to cross edges are called s-vertices and a-vertices , respectively. See Figure <ref> for an illustration.

* If v‚àà V(G) then the graph obtained from G by complementing the loop status of v is denoted G_‚Ñì^v.


  * If v‚àà V(G) then the graph obtained from G by complementing the adjacency status of every pair of neighbors of v is denoted G_s^v, and it is called the simple local complement of G with respect to v.


  * If v‚àà V(G) then the graph obtained from G by complementing the adjacency status of every pair of neighbors of v and the loop status of every neighbor of v is denoted G_ns^v, and it is called the non-simple local complement of G with respect to v.


  * A graph that can be obtained from G using loop complementations and local complementations is locally equivalent to G.

sentence:
Suppose vw is a nonloop edge of a simple
graph G. Then the edge pivot of G with respect to vw is

    G^vw=((G_s^v)_s^w)_s^v=((G_s^w)_s^v)_s^w.

If H can be obtained from G using edge pivots then G and H are pivot equivalent .

sentence:
A vertex-minor of a looped simple graph G is a graph obtained from
G through some sequence of local complementations, loop complementations
and vertex deletions.

sentence:
Let G be a looped simple graph. A pendant-twin reduction of G is a
graph obtained from G in one of the following ways:



  * Delete an isolated vertex.


  * Delete a twin vertex (adjacent or nonadjacent).


  * Delete a vertex of degree 1.

sentence: A Euler subgraph is a subgraph in which every vertex has even degree.

sentence: A compression is a function on the set of all graphs. The compression associated with a graph G from x to y for x,y ‚àà V(G), denoted by C_xy(G), moves all edges from (v,x) to (v,y) for v ‚àà V that it is possible to move without creating any double edges, preserving orientation if one exists.

sentence: Given a graph G, the line graph L(G) is the graph whose vertices are the edges of G, and two vertices x and y in L(G) are connected iff the corresponding edges share a common endpoint in G.

sentence: A split graph is a graph in which the vertices can be partitioned into a clique and an independent set.

sentence:
A homomorphism from a graph G to a graph H is a map
œï V(G)‚Üí V(H) such that uv‚àà E(G) implies œï(u)œï(v)‚àà E(H).
Such a map is an H-coloring ; the vertices of G are ‚Äúcolored‚Äù by
vertices of H.  Let K_p:q be the graph with vertex set _p in which
vertices are adjacent when they differ by at least q (see
Figure¬†<ref>).  A (p,q)-coloring of G is a homomorphism from
G into K_p:q.  A graph having a (p,q)-coloring is
(p,q)-colorable .  The circular chromatic number of G, written
(G), is inf{ pq G(p,q)-colorable}.

sentence:
A list assignment on a graph G is a map L giving each v‚àà V(G) a
set L(v) of colors called its list .  In a k-uniform list
assignment, each list has size k.  Given a list assignment L on G, an
L-coloring of G is a proper coloring œï of G such that
œï(v)‚àà L(v) for all v‚àà V(G).  A graph G is k-choosable if
G is L-colorable whenever each list has size at least k (we may assume
L is k-uniform).  The list chromatic number of G, written
(G), is the least k such that G is k-choosable.

A graph G is k-edge-choosable if G is L-edge-colorable whenever
each list has size at least k.  The list edge-chromatic number of G,
written '(G), is the least k such that G is k-edge-choosable.

and only if for each distinct T, T' in this set, T and T' are

BBF_n^q if and only if the set obtained by adding any other matrix

set on BBF_n^q having maximal cardinality is called
maximal cross-bibifix-free set on BBF_n^q.

  * {0} is the set-label of a vertex in G

  * the minimum number pendant vertices in G is cardinality of ‚Ñ¨.



Since the ground set X of an IASS-graph must contain the element 0, every subset A_i of X sum set of {0} and A_i itself. In this sense, each subset A_i may be considered as a trivial sum set of two subsets of X.  


In the following discussions, by a sum set of subsets of X, we mean the non-trivial sum sets of subsets of X.

sentence:
A share is a part of a chord diagram consisting
of two arcs of the outer circle possessing the following property:
each chord one of whose ends belongs to these arcs
has both ends on these arcs.

sentence:
An L-structure A is irreducible if for every distinct x, y ‚àà A, there is some R ‚àà L and a tuple t‚Éó containing x, y such that R(t‚Éó) holds in A.

A homomorphism f: A ‚Üí B is a homomorphism-embedding if f restricted to any irreducible substructure of A is an embedding, i.e. f is injective and for any R ‚àà L, R(x_1, ..., x_r) ‚áî R(f(x_1), ..., f(x_r)), where r is the arity of R.

Given an L-structure C and a class  of L-structures, we say C' is a -completion of C if C' ‚àà and there is a homomorphism-embedding f: C ‚Üí C'.

Given an L-structure C, an irreducible B ‚äÇ C, and a class  of L-structures, we say C' is a -completion of C with respect to copies of B if C' is an irreducible -structure and there is a function f:C ‚Üí C' such that f restricted to any BÃÇ‚àà C B is an embedding.

sentence:

sentence: Let X be a structure, and E ‚â§ F equivalence relations on X. A subquotient-order from E to F is a partial order on X/E in which two E-classes are comparable iff they lie in the same F-class (note, this pulls back to a partial order on X). Thus, this partial order provides a linear order of C/E for each C ‚àà X/F. We call E the bottom relation and F the top relation of the subquotient-order.

Let M and N be matroids on the same ground set E. We say that N is a quotient of M if one of the following equivalent statements holds:

  *  There exists a matroid R and a subset X of E(R) such that M=R\ X and N=R/X. 
		
  * For all bases B of M, x ‚àâ B, there is a basis B' of N with B' ‚äÜ B and such that {y: (B'-y)‚à™ x ‚àà‚Ñ¨(N)}‚äÜ{y: (B-y)‚à™ x ‚àà‚Ñ¨(M)}.

sentence:
A non-crossing geometric tree of order n is a tree whose vertices form a set of n points in 
 convex position in the plane, and any two edges may intersect only in a common vertex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For every n, the geometric tree graph ùí¢_n, is the graph
which has as vertices all the geometric trees of order n on a given set of vertices 
(in convex position), and there is an edge
between trees T and S if there exist edges e of T and f of S such that S = T - e + f, 
namely S is obtained by removing e from T and adding f.
Geometric tree graphs were studied by Hernando, Hurtado, Marquez, Mora and Noy <cit.>.

sentence: A fixed point free involution  is a permutation only composed of 2-cycles. A chord diagram with n chords is a graphical representation of a fixed point free involution on the set {0,1,2,‚Ä¶, 2n-1}, in which we draw points 0,1,2,‚Ä¶,2n-1 on a horizontal line from left to right, and we join by a chord every two elements belonging to a same cycle. The root chord of a chord diagram is the chord including the point 0.

sentence:
The intersection order of the chords of a rooted connected diagram C is defined as follows.

  
  * The root chord of C is the first chord in the intersection order.
  
  * Remove the root chord of C and let C_1, C_2, ‚Ä¶, C_k be the connected components of the result ordered by their first vertex.
  
  * For the intersection order of C, after the root chord come all the chords of C_1 ordered recursively in the intersection order, then all the chords of C_2 ordered by intersection order, and so on.

sentence:
The peeling order of an indecomposable diagram D is defined as follows. 
  
  
  * The root chord of D is the first chord in the peeling order.
  
  * Remove the root chord of D. The result is not necessarily indecomposable. Let D_1, D_2, ‚Ä¶, D_k be the indecomposable diagrams we obtain from left to right.
  
  * For the peeling order of D, after the root chord come all the chord of D_k ordered recursively in the peeling order, then all the chords of D_k-1 ordered recursively, and so on.

sentence: The principle of the rightmost DFS is the following. Starting from the root, we explore the map as far as possible by choosing at each newly visited vertex the nearest half-edge in clockwise order. If the other associated half-edge belongs to an already visited vertex, we backtrack. We stop once every edge has been visited.

sentence:
[Intersection graph, connected diagrams]

The intersection graph of a chord diagram C is defined as the digraph with a vertex for every chord, and an oriented edge from chord (a,b) to chord (c,d) whenever a < c < b < d.
A chord diagram is said to be connected (or irreducible ) if its intersection graph is (weakly) connected.

sentence:
A pair (T,X) is a tree decomposition of a graph G=(V,E)
  if T is a tree with node set I and X maps nodes of T to
  subsets of V (called bags ) such that
  
  
  *  
    ‚àÄ v ‚àà V ,‚àÉ i ‚àà I,  v ‚àà X(i);
  
  * 
    ‚àÄ uv ‚àà E, ‚àÉ i ‚àà I, {u,v}‚äÜ X(i);
  
  * 
    ‚àÄ v ‚àà V,   T[{i | v ‚àà X(i)}] is connected.
  
  The width of (T,X) is max_i ‚àà I |X(i)|-1 and the
  treewidth of G is the minimum width of a tree decomposition of G.
  It is denoted as (G).

sentence:
A 3-cutset in a 3-connected graph is a subset of three vertices whose deletion would disconnect the remaining graph.
A cutset is trivial if it consists of the three neighbours of a degree-three vertex, and non-trivial otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: The barycentric subdivision (G) of a 3-connected planar graph G has a vertex for each vertex, edge, or face of the unique planar embedding of G. It has an edge for each incident vertex-edge, vertex-face, or edge-face pair in¬†G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A canonical cycle is an induced 6-cycle in  (G) that alternates between vertices of G and non-vertices of G such that, whenever two vertices u and v of G belong to the cycle and are adjacent in¬†G, the canonical cycle follows the path u‚Äìuv‚Äìv in (G). Additionally, we require that the six vertices of the induced cycle not be the six neighbours of a triangular face of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The conflict graph (H) of a graph H is another graph, with vertices in one-to-one correspondence with the canonical cycles in H. Two vertices in (H) are adjacent if and only if they correspond to a non-laminar pair of canonical cycles.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
In¬†(G), we define an allowable cycle to be an induced 6-cycle that avoids the following forbidden configurations:


  * paths of the form x‚Äìf‚Äìy, where x and y are adjacent vertices of G that both belong to the same face f of G, and

  * paths of the form f_1‚Äìx‚Äìf_2 (where f_1 and f_2 are the two faces of G that share edge xy).

  * cycles in which all six vertices have a common neighbour.

sentence: If C is an allowable cycle, we define a shift of C to be the cycle formed by replacing each path in C of the form f_1‚Äìe‚Äìf_2 (where e is an edge of G and f_1 and f_2 are the two incident faces) by one of the two paths of the form f_1‚Äìx‚Äìf_2 or f_1‚Äìy‚Äìf_2 (where x and y are the two endpoints of e), and then replacing each path in C of the form u‚Äìf‚Äìv where u and v are adjacent in G by the path u‚Äìuv‚Äìv.

sentence:
For k‚â• 4, a k-frame (a,b,P_1,..,P_k) is a structure of (G) in which:


  * Both a and b are  vertices of  (G).

  * Each P_i is an induced three-edge path from a to b.

  * Each two distinct paths P_i and P_j are internally vertex disjoint.

  * The paths are numbered in their cyclic ordering (or its reverse) around a and b in the given planar embedding.

  * None of the paths P_i contain one of the v‚Äìf‚Äìv or f‚Äìv‚Äìf triples that are forbidden in an allowable cycle.

The poles of the frame are the vertices a and b.

sentence: A k-frame is maximal if there does not exist a (k+1)-frame with the same two poles and a superset of the same paths.

sentence: A big frame is a frame in (G) that has ten or more paths.

sentence: An allowable subgraph is a subgraph of (G) with the property that every canonical cycle in the subgraph is a shift of an allowable cycle that is also in the subgraph.

sentence:
Vertex set B‚äÜ V(G) is called a centroidal locating set
of graph G if r(x)‚â† r(y) for every pair x,y of distinct
vertices. A centroidal basis of G is a centroidal locating
set of minimum cardinality. The centroidal dimension of G,
denoted (G), is the cardinality of a centroidal basis.

sentence:
A mobile is a planar tree ‚Äì that is, a map with a single face ‚Äì such that there are two kinds of vertices (black and white), edges only occur as black‚Äìblack edges or black‚Äìwhite edges, and black vertices additionally have so-called ‚Äúlegs‚Äù attached to them (which are not considered edges), whose number equals the number of white neighbor vertices. 

A bipartite mobile is  a mobile without black‚Äìblack edges. 

The degree of a black vertex is the number of half-edges plus the number of legs that are 
attached to it. 

A mobile is called rooted if an edge is distinguished and oriented.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: A Motzkin path is a path starting at 0 and going rightwards for a number of steps; the steps are either diagonally upwards (+1), straight (0) or diagonally downwards (-1). A Motzkin bridge is a Motzkin path from 0 to 0. A Motzkin excursion is a Motzkin bridge which stays non-negative.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given g ‚àà‚Ñ§_‚â• 0, a g-mobile is a one-faced map of genus g ‚Äì embedded on the g-torus ‚Äì such that there are two kinds of vertices (black and white), edges only occur as black‚Äìblack edges or black‚Äìwhite edges, and black vertices additionally have so-called ‚Äúlegs‚Äù attached to them (which are not considered edges), whose number equals the number of white neighbor vertices.

Furthermore, for each cycle c of the g-mobile, let  n_‚àò, n_‚Üí and n_ respectively be the numbers of white vertices on c, of legs dangling to the left of c and of white neighbours to the left of c. One has the following constraint (see Figure¬†<ref>):

    n_‚Üí = n_‚àò + n_

The degree of a black vertex is the number of half-edges plus the number of legs that are 
attached to it.
A bipartite g-mobile is a g-mobile without black‚Äìblack edges.
A g-mobile is called rooted if an edge is distinguished and oriented.

Notice that a 0-mobile is simply a mobile as described in Definition¬†<ref>.

sentence: An elementary cell is a half-edge connected to a black vertex itself connected to a white vertex with a dangling half-edge. The white vertex has a sequence of black-rooted mobiles attached on each side. The black vertex has j‚â•0 legs and k‚â•0 white-rooted mobiles on its left, l‚â• 0 white-rooted mobiles and k+l-j+2 legs on its right, and its degree is 2(k+l+2). The increment of the cell is then j-k-1.

sentence:
A tree T is a collection of non-empty finite sets of integers such that if œÉ‚àà T and ‚àÖ‚â†œÑ‚äÜœÉ then œÑ‚àà T.  We write œÉ<n if m<n for all m‚àà FS(œÉ).  We write œÉ<œÑ if œÑ is nonempty and œÉ<n for every n‚àà FS(œÑ).  We write œÉ<T if œÉ<œÑ for every œÑ‚àà T.

We write FS(T) for ‚ãÉ_œÉ‚àà TFS(œÉ).  If T,T' are trees, we write T'‚äÜ_FST if FS(T')‚äÜ FS(T).

If œÉ‚àà T, we define a new tree, T-œÉ, by setting œÑ‚àà (T-œÉ) iff œÉ<œÑ and œÉ‚à™œÑ‚àà T.  When œÉ<T, T+œÉ is the tree generated by T‚à™{œÉ‚à™œÑ|œÑ‚àà T}.

We may view T as being partially ordered by the relation œÉ‚â∫œÑ iff œÑ‚äÜœÉ and there is a œÉ'‚äÜœÉ such that œÑ<œÉ'.  We write ht(T) for the ordinal height of T under this ordering if it is well-founded, and ht(T)=‚àû if T is ill-founded.

Given two edges e,f‚àà E(G) and a vertex x‚àà V(G), we say that x

cardinality, the incidence dimension of G, is denoted by dim_I(G).

For a plane graph G, a list assignment L from Theorem¬†<ref>, and p‚àà V(G) with |L(p)|=1, the pair (G,L) is prime if

and in addition (G,L) contains none of the configurations (C<ref>)‚Äì(C<ref>) below:

  *  A 3-face incident to at most one high vertex.


  *  A diamond  xz_1yz_2 where d(z_1) = d(z_2) =3 and d(x)=d(y) = 4.


  *  A diamond  xz_1yz_2 where d(y) = 4 and d(x) = 3.

A facial K_4 wxyz where w is the internal vertex, and at least one of x, y, and z has degree at most 4.






    < g r a p h i c s >

Simple reducible configurations.
  









    < g r a p h i c s >

Compound reducible configurations.
  






  *  A facial K_4 wxyz where w is the internal vertex, the vertex z has degree exactly five, and the other two neighbors u,v of z bound a bad 3-face zvu.



  *  A diamond  xz_1yz_2 where d(z_1)=d(z_2) = 3, d(x) = 4, d(y) = 5, and the other two neighbors u,v of y form a bad 3-face yvu.


  *  A diamond  xz_1yz_2 where d(x) = 3, d(y) = 5, and the other two neighbors u,v of y form a bad 3-face yvu.

  *  A bad 3-face xyz and a normal 4-face wuvx where d(x)=4 and x is the only high vertex incident to the 4-face.


  *  Two 3-faces xyz and xuv where d(x)=4 and d(y) = d(v) = 3.


  *  
Three 3-faces xyz, xuv, vpq, where d(y) = d(p) = 3 and d(x) = d(v) = 4.

sentence:
[Slater¬†<cit.>]
A set S of vertices of a graph G is a locating-dominating
set if it is a dominating set and it separates the vertices of
V(G)‚àñ S.
The smallest size of a locating-dominating set of G is the location-domination number of 
G, denoted (G). Without the domination constraint, this concept has also been used under the 
name distinguishing set in¬†<cit.> and sieve in¬†<cit.>.

sentence:
[Karpovsky, Chakrabarty and Levitin¬†<cit.>]
A set S of vertices of a graph G is an identifying code if
it is a dominating set and it separates all vertices of V(G).
The smallest size of an identifying code of G is the
identifying code number of G, denoted (G).

sentence:
[Seo and Slater¬†<cit.>]
A set S of vertices of a graph G is an open
locating-dominating set if it is a total dominating set and it
totally separates all vertices of V(G).
The smallest size of an open locating-dominating set of G is the
open location-domination number of G, denoted (G). This
concept has also been called identifying open code
in¬†<cit.>.

locating sets¬†<cit.>. Optimal resolving sets have
sometimes been called metric bases in the literature; to
avoid an inflation in the terminology we will only use the term
resolving set .]
The smallest size of a resolving set of G is the metric dimension of G, denoted 
(G).

(T)
=
_x_1,‚Ä¶,x_d‚àà^nœá(T(x_1,‚Ä¶,x_d)).

sentence:
A labeled seed in¬†‚Ñ± is
a triple (ùê±, ùê≤, B), where


  * ùê± = (x_1, ‚Ä¶, x_N) is an N-tuple
from ‚Ñ±
forming a free generating set over ‚Ñô,

  * ùê≤ = (y_1, ‚Ä¶, y_N) is an N-tuple
from ‚Ñô, and

  * B = (b_ij) is an N√ó N integer matrix
which is skew-symmetrizable .

That is, x_1, ‚Ä¶, x_N
are algebraically independent over¬†‚Ñô, and
‚Ñ± = ‚Ñô(x_1, ‚Ä¶, x_N).
We refer to¬†ùê± as the (labeled)
cluster of a labeled seed (ùê±, ùê≤, B),
to the tuple¬†ùê≤ as the coefficient tuple , and to the
matrix¬†B as the exchange matrix .

sentence:
Let (ùê±, ùê≤, B) be a labeled seed in ‚Ñ±,
and let k ‚àà [1,N].
The seed mutation Œº_k in direction¬†k transforms
(ùê±, ùê≤, B) into the labeled seed
Œº_k(ùê±, ùê≤, B)=(ùê±', ùê≤', B') defined as follows:


  * The entries of B'=(b'_ij) are given by

    b'_ij =
    
    -b_ij   if i=k or j=k;
    
    b_ij + (b_ik)  [b_ikb_kj]_+
        otherwise.


  * The coefficient tuple ùê≤'=(y_1',‚Ä¶,y_N') is given by

    y'_j =
    
    y_k^-1   if j = k;
    
    y_j y_k^[b_kj]_+
    (y_k ‚äï 1)^- b_kj   if j ‚â† k.


  * The cluster ùê±'=(x_1',‚Ä¶,x_N') is given by
x_j'=x_j for j‚â† k,
whereas x'_k ‚àà‚Ñ± is determined
by the exchange relation

    x'_k = y_k  ‚àè x_i^[b_ik]_+
    +  ‚àè x_i^[-b_ik]_+/(y_k ‚äï 1) x_k  .

sentence:
Consider the N-regular tree¬†ùïã_N
whose edges are labeled by the numbers 1, ‚Ä¶, N,
so that the N edges emanating from each vertex receive
different labels.
A cluster pattern  is an assignment
of a labeled seed Œ£_t=(ùê±_t, ùê≤_t, B_t)
to every vertex t ‚ààùïã_N, such that the seeds assigned to the
endpoints of any edge t k   t' are obtained from each
other by the seed mutation in direction¬†k.
The components of Œ£_t are written as:

    ùê±_t = (x_1;t ,‚Ä¶,x_N;t) ,  ùê≤_t = (y_1;t ,‚Ä¶,y_N;t) ,  
    B_t = (b^t_ij) .

sentence:
Given a cluster pattern, we denote

    ùí≥
    = ‚ãÉ_t ‚ààùïã_Nùê±_t
    = { x_i;t :  t ‚ààùïã_N , 1‚â§ i‚â§ N } ,

the union of clusters from all seeds in the pattern.
The elements x_i;t‚ààùí≥ are called cluster variables .
The
cluster algebra ùíú associated with a
given pattern is the ‚Ñô-subalgebra of the ambient field ‚Ñ±
generated by all cluster variables: ùíú = ‚Ñô[ùí≥].
We denote ùíú = ùíú(ùê±, ùê≤, B), where
(ùê±,ùê≤,B)
is any seed in the underlying cluster pattern.

Suppose w‚ààŒ£^* such that w=v_k^n_kv_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ v_0^n_0 where for every integer 0‚â§ i‚â§ k, we have v_i‚ààŒ£^+ with Œ®_Œ£(v_i)=B_i. Then, _r(w)=v_k^n_kv_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ v_0^n_0 and w is ‚â∫-maximal.

sentence:
Suppose Œ£ is an ordered alphabet with |Œ£|=s and M‚ààùí´_Œ£^+. 



  * 


  * Define Œº(M)=max{  n‚àà‚Ñï  |  M=A¬∑ B^n  for some A‚ààùí´_Œ£ and  B‚ààùí´_Œ£^+ }.


  * Define œÉ(M) to be the sum of the entries in the second diagonal of M.



  * Define œë(M) as follows:


  * if Œº(M)=1, then 
œë(M) is defined to be the minimum element of the following set:

    { œÉ(B)  |  B‚ààùí´_Œ£^+  and 
    M=A¬∑ B  for some  A‚ààùí´_Œ£^+} with Œº(A)‚â† 1},

provided it is nonempty; otherwise, it is defined to be œÉ(M);

  * if Œº(M)>1, then  œë(M) is defined to be the maximum element of the following set:

    { œÉ(B)  |    B‚ààùí´_Œ£^+  and 
    M=A¬∑ B^Œº(M) for some  A‚ààùí´_Œ£}.



  * Define S_M={  (A,B,Œº(M))  |  A‚ààùí´_Œ£ and  B‚ààùí´_Œ£^+    with  M=A¬∑ B^Œº(M) and œÉ(B)=œë(M) }. 



Let k be a nonnegative integer. For every integer 0‚â§ i‚â§ k, suppose B_i‚ààùí´_Œ£ and n_i‚àà‚Ñï. We say that B_k^n_kB_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ B_0^n_0 is a rl-Parikh normal form of M if and only if the following holds:

Let A_0=M, A_i=B_k^n_kB_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ B_i^n_i (1‚â§ i‚â§ k) and A_k+1=I_s+1.

Then (A_i+1,B_i,n_i)‚àà S_A_i for all 0‚â§ i‚â§ k.

Equivalently, we say that M is rl-Parikh normalized to the form B_k^n_kB_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ B_0^n_0.

sentence:
Suppose Œ£ is an alphabet and w‚ààŒ£^+. 



  * Define R_w={ (u,v,n)‚ààŒ£^*√óŒ£^+√ó‚Ñï  |  w=uv^n }.


  * Define œÑ(w)=max{ n‚àà‚Ñï  | (u,v,n)‚àà R_w  for some u‚ààŒ£^*  and  v‚ààŒ£^+ }.


  * Define Œ∏(w) as follows:


  * if œÑ(w)=1, then Œ∏(w) is defined to be the minimum element of the following set:

    { |v|  |  v‚ààŒ£^+  and 
    w=uv  for some  u‚ààŒ£^+ with œÑ(u)‚â† 1},

provided it is nonempty; otherwise Œ∏(w)=|w|.

  * if œÑ(w)>1, then Œ∏(w) is defined to be the maximum element of the following set:

    { |v|  |  v‚ààŒ£^+  and 
    w=uv^œÑ(w) for some  u‚ààŒ£^+}.




  * Define œÅ(w)=(u',v',œÑ(w)) to be the unique triplet in R_w such that |v'|=Œ∏(w).


  * Let w_0=w and (w_1,v_0,n_0)=œÅ(w_0). For all integers i‚â• 1 and while w_i‚â†Œª, recursively define (w_i+1,v_i,n_i)=œÅ(w_i). Let k‚â• 1 be the largest integer such that w_k‚â†Œª. 

We say that v_k^n_kv_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ v_0^n_0 is the rl-Parikh normal form of w, denoted by _r(w). Equivalently, we say that w is rl-Parikh normalized to the form v_k^n_kv_k-1^n_k-1‚ãØ v_0^n_0.

sentence: Suppose Œ£ is an ordered alphabet. We say that the word w is maximal with respect to the relation ‚â∫ (or simply ‚â∫-maximal ), if and only if there exists no other word w'‚àà C_w such that w‚â∫ w'.

sentence:
Suppose Œ£={a_1<a_2< ‚Ä¶<a_s} is an ordered alphabet, where s‚â• 2. The Parikh matrix mapping with respect to Œ£, denoted by Œ®_Œ£, is the morphism

    Œ®_Œ£: Œ£^*‚Üí‚Ñ≥_s+1

defined as follows: Œ®_Œ£(Œª)=I_s+1; if  Œ®_Œ£(a_q)=M, then M_i,i=1 for each 1‚â§ i‚â§ s+1, M_q,q+1=1 and all other entries of the matrix Œ®_Œ£(a_q) are zero. Matrices of the form  Œ®_Œ£(w) for w‚ààŒ£^* are called Parikh matrices . We denote by ùí´_Œ£ the set of all Parikh matrices with respect to Œ£ and let ùí´_Œ£^+=ùí´_Œ£\{I_s+1}.

Suppose Œ£ is an ordered alphabet.
Two words w,w'‚ààŒ£^* are M-equivalent , denoted by w‚â°_Mw', iff Œ®_Œ£(w)=Œ®_Œ£(w').
A word w‚ààŒ£^* is M-ambiguous iff it is M-equivalent to another distinct word. Otherwise, w is M-unambiguous . We denote the M-equivalence class of a word w‚ààŒ£^* by C_w.
